subject: Fix password $-escaping in cobbler kickstart templates
commit_message:
Fix password $-escaping in cobbler kickstart templates

Cobbler uses Cheetah rendering engine which treats $ as template
sign. All non-related to templating $ should be escaped.

Non-escaped $ leads to templating failure in cobbler which triggers
dnsmasq restart. Multiple dnsmasq restarts in a short period of time
could lead to harmful dns resolition failure during OS installation.

In order to fix templating failures, all exposed passwords should be
surrounded by 'raw escaping' block.

Eg.:
 #raw
 foo = $foo
 #end raw

Change-Id: Id16646ed1e19fce71931235aae67227c0a7433da
Related-Bug: 1458533

subject: Integrate PD Reference Implementation with neutron db/agent
commit_message:
Integrate PD Reference Implementation with neutron db/agent

This patch implements IPv6 Prefix Delegation for automatic allocation
of subnet CIDRs in Neutron. This allows automatic allocation of IPv6
subnet prefixes to be offloaded to an external DHCPv6 prefix
delegation server maintained by the OpenStack deployer.

To enable this feature, subnets have been given a new property,
ipv6_pd_enabled. This property is hidden and does not affect the Neutron API.

WORKFLOW:

1. Admin sets default_ipv6_subnet_pool in neutron.conf to "prefix_delegation"
2. User creates a new IPv6 subnet without a CIDR or subnetpool ID
3. User creates an interface between this subnet and a router with an existing
external interface

A patch for admin/user documentation is up for review here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/178739

Video guides for configuring and using this feature are available on
YouTube:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wI830s881HQ
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zfsFyS01Fn0

Change-Id: Ib681b9a2a509b5c2883111251b20082f6442e2ed

subject: Python sessions, streaming, and increased pool
commit_message:
Python sessions, streaming, and increased pool

Since glance started using python-swiftclient 2.0.8 it has been seeing
WARNING requests.packages.urllib3.connectionpool [-] HttpConnectionPool
is full, discarding connection: messages.

The pool (a LifoQueue) is configured to be quite small by default. When
a connection is requested using a pool, a connection is taken from the
pool. If there are no connections in the pool, a new connection is
created (unless blocking is enabled). When the user is done with the
connection, it is put back into the queue. If the queue is already full,
it is discarded, and an "HttpConnectionPool is full, discarding
connection" message is generated. When the queue is too small, many new
connections will be created and because the pool can fill and empty so
quickly many of the connections will be discarded.

Special care has to be taken with streams. Since streams don't download
all of the data at once, if all the data is not read, the connection
must be explicitly freed.

This patch updates the pool size and enables streams only for get and
put object by default and makes them user configurable.

Change-Id: I53e6ae9c316d64267fde769586eaf5ae2791e7d8
Closes-Bug: 1295812

VM configuration files are stored. The files are being stored in the same
folder as the instance. Performing a cold resize / migration will cause a
os.rename call on the instance's folder, which fails as long as there are
configuration files used by Hyper-V in that folder, thus resulting in a
failed migration and the instance ending up in ERROR state.

folder (e.g.: C:\OpenStack\Instances\instance-000000b6\Virtual Machines).

This commit makes sure that Hyper-V configuration files are not being
moved during migration by skipping subfolders in the instance's folder.

Create object files directly in datadir.

Prior to this change, all object files were initially created in
the "tmp" directory which was created directly under the disk
mount point (e.g. /srv/node/r0/tmp). XFS creates files in the
same allocation group as its parent directory. As a result all files
were getting created in the same allocation group and performance
of XFS dropped significantly very quickly.

This commit fixes the above problem by doing the following:
1. Creates a temperory file with the extension ".objtmp" directly in
   the final data directory.
2. Creates a symlink to this file under the "tmp" directory.
3. If the PUT succeeds, the objtmp file is renamed to .data as earlier
   and the symlink is deleted.
4. If the PUT fails, the object replicator now deletes the symlinks
   as well as any stale .objtmp files.
5. Stale .objtmp files are also deleted while cleaning up the hash
   directory.

subject: Make HAProxy check of swift proxy backends via management VIP
commit_message:
Make HAProxy check of swift proxy backends via management VIP

W/o this fix, when the management interface on the controller node
running a Swift proxy is down, HAProxy would fail to update
its backend status at the storage network.

This is a problem as we want swift backends not able to connect the
swift endpoint via the management VIP to be marked down. Othewise,
responces time for any requested swift commands would be drastically
longer. Simple httpcheck option cannot resolve this because the swift
healthcheck reports OK, if conntacted via the storage network.

In order to fix this, simple healthcheck script is implemented.
This script is running as HTTP xinetid service at TCP port 49001 and
is accessible only from the localhost, 240.0.0.2, and storage plus
management networks. The service verifies the node under check for the:
a) management VIP is pingable via ICMP (by 3 packets)
b) Swift endpoint is reachable by TCP-connect via the local storage address
within 5 seconds connection timeout
c) Swift healthcheck report via the local storage address endpoint is OK

Reports an HTTP 200 OK, if all of the results are OK.
Otherwise, it would report an HTTP 503 Error.
Expected Swift node control plane failover time will be around 30 seconds.
Swift data plane is not affected.

DocImpact: Reference architecture, swift failover.

Closes-bug: #1459772
Related-bug: #1460623

Change-Id: I55a35b45257763a20f33bd47cb5c57de53558ccf

subject: User should be able to update allocation pool values.
commit_message:
User should be able to update allocation pool values.

Steps to reproduce it:
1. Select an existing subnet.
2. In the subnet detail, change the allocation pools value.
3. Click Save.
4. Click the changed subnet detail and check the allocation pool value.

Root cause: The problem is that we only allow a new subnet to set the allocation pool.
Seems like we can do that via api during update and so we should enable that on Horizon.
